articles.headline: Venezuela, Accustomed to Tragedy, Is Shaken Again by Horrific Jail Fire
articles.snippet: With at least 68 dead, the inferno in Valencia was one of the worst in the country’s modern history.
articles.abstract: With at least 68 dead, the inferno in Valencia was one of the worst in the country’s modern history.
articles.lead_paragraph: VALENCIA, Venezuela — It began as a jailhouse party. It ended in carnage.
articles.byline: By Ana Vanessa Herrero and Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: Expelling Diplomats, a Furious Kremlin Escalates a Crisis
articles.snippet: The move was in retaliation for the expulsion of diplomats by Britain, the United States and their allies. The U.S. Consulate in St. Petersburg will be closed.
articles.abstract: The move was in retaliation for the expulsion of diplomats by Britain, the United States and their allies. The U.S. Consulate in St. Petersburg will be closed.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia on Thursday escalated a confrontation with Europe and the United States over the poisoning of a former Russian spy in Britain, saying it would expel 60 American diplomats and an unspecified number of envoys from other countries to retaliate for a mass expulsion of Russian diplomats working in the West and beyond that was ordered this week.

articles.headline: Tesla Looked Like the Future. Now Some Ask if It Has One.
articles.snippet: Production delays, a recall and other problems have presented the electric-car maker and its founder, Elon Musk, with a crisis of confidence among investors.
articles.abstract: Production delays, a recall and other problems have presented the electric-car maker and its founder, Elon Musk, with a crisis of confidence among investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a year ago, Tesla looked like a rising force destined to revolutionize the auto industry.

articles.headline: ‘Roseanne’ Reboot Sprang From ABC’s Heartland Strategy After Trump’s Victory
articles.snippet: The network realized it was leaving some viewers behind — and put into effect a plan that brought back a working-class sitcom.
articles.abstract: The network realized it was leaving some viewers behind — and put into effect a plan that brought back a working-class sitcom.
articles.lead_paragraph: UPDATE: ABC canceled “Roseanne” on May 29, after the show’s star and co-creator, Roseanne Barr, posted a racist tweet. Read about the tweet and the cancellation here.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Wooing Saudi Business, Tabloid Mogul Had a Powerful Friend: Trump
articles.snippet: A dinner at the White House helped David J. Pecker, whose company owns The National Enquirer, showcase his connections as he sought to expand into Saudi Arabia.
articles.abstract: A dinner at the White House helped David J. Pecker, whose company owns The National Enquirer, showcase his connections as he sought to expand into Saudi Arabia.
articles.lead_paragraph: In July, David J. Pecker, the chairman of the company that owns The National Enquirer, visited his old friend President Trump at the White House.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Kate Kelly, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Warms to Trump After a Chilly Start
articles.snippet: Even though Mr. Trump still takes potshots at Amazon, the industry’s relationship with the White House is shifting as tech companies find some common ground with the president.
articles.abstract: Even though Mr. Trump still takes potshots at Amazon, the industry’s relationship with the White House is shifting as tech companies find some common ground with the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Two days after Donald J. Trump won the 2016 election, executives at Google consoled their employees in an all-staff meeting broadcast around the world.

articles.headline: Going Cashless: My Journey Into the Future
articles.snippet: So far in 2018, I have hardly touched paper money or metal coins. There are no grimy bills folded alongside my driver’s license, no quarters or pennies jangling in my pocket.
articles.abstract: So far in 2018, I have hardly touched paper money or metal coins. There are no grimy bills folded alongside my driver’s license, no quarters or pennies jangling in my pocket.
articles.lead_paragraph: I didn’t mean to do it. It just sort of happened. But what began with an empty wallet on New Year’s Day has evolved into something akin to a lifestyle change.

articles.headline: Israeli Military Kills 15 Palestinians in Confrontations on Gaza Border
articles.snippet: What was promoted as a six-week campaign of peaceful protests, with thousands of Palestinians in tent cities, descended quickly into deadly violence.
articles.abstract: What was promoted as a six-week campaign of peaceful protests, with thousands of Palestinians in tent cities, descended quickly into deadly violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Tens of thousands of Palestinians gathered along Gaza’s border with Israel on Friday to vent their pent-up frustration in a protest that quickly turned violent, with Israeli forces killing 15 at the border fence.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Iyad Abuheweila

articles.headline: A Student Loan Fix for a Teacher, and Many Other Public Servants
articles.snippet: The complexity of the public service loan forgiveness program has tripped up many teachers like Jed Shafer. An October Your Money column led to changes.
articles.abstract: The complexity of the public service loan forgiveness program has tripped up many teachers like Jed Shafer. An October Your Money column led to changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In October, I wrote a column about Jed Shafer, a teacher in Oregon who found himself on the wrong end of the student loan repayment bureaucracy.
